newsitem.title: UK: Treasuries drift lower in London, await key data.
newsitem.headline: Treasuries drift lower in London, await key data.

text.p: U.S. Treasuries dipped lower in London in slim volumes on Wednesday, with little to shift the market before payrolls data on Friday.

Traders had expected comments from Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan at the International Monetary Conference in Switzerland to provide a diversion but he pulled out of the news conference because of travel arrangements.
"There's very little going on," a trader at a U.S. bank in London said. "There's been a little bit of liquidation from some accounts out of Japan."
At 1015 GMT, the long bond was quoted at 96-22, down from 96-27 in Tokyo and 96-29 at the close in New York on Tuesday.
September T-bond futures were quoted at 110-01, down 2/32 in automated trade.
Greenspan was due attend a news briefing with Bank of France Governor Jean-Claude Trichet at the IMC.
April factory orders at 1400 GMT, were expected to have risen 0.8 percent after a 1.6 percent drop in March but the real focus for the market would be May payrolls on Friday.
Economists have revised down their payroll estimates after the Bureau of Labor Statistics changed its seasonal adjustment factors on the data.
Economists polled by Reuters now expected jobs growth of 219,000 for the month compared to an initial consensus of 221,000.
Mark Henry, analyst at GNI Ltd in London, said the unemployment rate would be key for the market after the drop in April to a 24-year low of 4.9 percent.
"If we see that kind of level again Treasuries will look closely at it," he said.
He said the market was still likely to turn defensive ahead of the data after robust figures from the National Association of Purchasing Management and recent strong consumer confidence data.
